prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We estimate the rms to detect $YSigma_{H2}=10$ $M_Yodot$ pc$^{-2}$ at the $5Ysigma$ level. The $1Ysigma$ rms is evaluated to be 2.66 mJy/beam using metallicity dependent conversion factor $Yalpha_{CO}$ of Genzel et al. (2012). We set the velocity resolution of $10$ km s$^{-1}$ assuming the molecular clump velocity width of $10$ km s$^{-1}$. The 468 MHz bandwidth is selected with referred to the CO line width obtained in previous study (Puschnig et al. 2015 in prep).

Puschnig et al. (2015 in prep) have found CO($J=1-0$) emission from this galaxy whose the line width $V_{CO}$ is $V_{CO}=297$ km s$^{-1}. In order to detect CO($J=1-0$) line and perform the profile fitting more accurately, we need the bandwidth more than $V_{CO}+600$ km s$^{-1} ($Ypm300$ km s$^{-1}$ about CO line). Thus we select 468 MHz bandwidth.

The galaxy has its diameter of $7.78$ kpc corresponding to $10.32''$ which is smaller than a single pointing. However the diameter is larger than the inner third of FoV which is the boundary of the sensitivity drop off. Thus we set a $9$-point mosaic observations to achieve an uniform sensitivity over the entire region of this galaxy. The galaxy spread over $40''$ including tail-like structure, we also request the ACA use to detect the bulk CO flux from this galaxy.

We estimate the rms to detect $YSigma_{H2}=10$ $M_Yodot$ pc$^{-2}$ at the $5Ysigma$ level. The $1Ysigma$ rms is evaluated to be 1.11 mJy/beam using metallicity dependent conversion factor $Yalpha_{CO}$ of Genzel et al. (2012). We set the velocity resolution of $5$ km s$^{-1}$ assuming the molecular clump velocity width of $5$ km s$^{-1}$. The 468 MHz bandwidth is selected with referred to the CO line width obtained in previous study (Puschnig et al. 2015 in prep).

Puschnig et al. (2015 in prep) have found CO($J=1-0$) emission from this galaxy whose the line width $V_{CO}$ is $V_{CO}=141$ km s$^{-1}. In order to detect CO($J=1-0$) line and perform the profile fitting more accurately, we need the bandwidth more than $V_{CO}+600$ km s$^{-1} ($Ypm300$ km s$^{-1}$ about CO line). Thus we select 468 MHz bandwidth.

The galaxy has its diameter of $13.62$ kpc corresponding to $8.62''$ which is smaller than a single pointing. However the diameter is larger than the inner third of FoV which is the boundary of the sensitivity drop off. Thus we set a $9$-point mosaic observations to achieve an uniform sensitivity over the entire region of this galaxy.

We estimate the rms to detect $YSigma_{H2}=10$ $M_Yodot$ pc$^{-2}$ at the $5Ysigma$ level. The $1Ysigma$ rms is evaluated to be 3.24 mJy/beam using metallicity dependent conversion factor $Yalpha_{CO}$ of Genzel et al. (2012). The 468 MHz bandwidth is selected with referred to the CO line width obtained in previous study (Puschnig et al. 2015 in prep).

Puschnig et al. (2015 in prep) have found CO($J=1-0$) emission from this galaxy whose the line width $V_{CO}$ is $V_{CO}=213$ km s$^{-1}. In order to detect CO($J=1-0$) line and perform the profile fitting more accurately, we need the bandwidth more than $V_{CO}+600$ km s$^{-1} ($Ypm300$ km s$^{-1}$ about CO line). Thus we select 468 MHz bandwidth.

The galaxy has its diameter of $9.36$ kpc corresponding to $3.64''$, which is small enough to cover a single pointing. To resolve molecular clumps on $Ysim1$ kpc scale, we choose $0.3"$ angular resolution.

We estimate the rms to detect $YSigma_{H2}=10$ $M_Yodot$ pc$^{-2}$ at the $5Ysigma$ level. The $1Ysigma$ rms is evaluated to be 7.74 mJy/beam using metallicity dependent conversion factor $Yalpha_{CO}$ of Genzel et al. (2012). We set the velocity resolution of $10$ km s$^{-1}$ assuming the molecular clump velocity width of $10$ km s$^{-1}$. The 468 MHz bandwidth is selected with referred to the CO line width obtained in previous study (Goncalves et al. 2014).

Goncalves et al. (2014) have found CO($J=1-0$) emission from this galaxy. Since this galaxy is merger, detected CO line shows a wide line width of $>400$ km s$^{-1}$. In order to cover this wide line width and perform the profile fitting more accurately, we need the bandwidth more than $1000$ km s$^{-1} ($Ypm300$ km s$^{-1}$ about CO line). Thus we select 468 MHz bandwidth.

The galaxy has its diameter of $5.40$ kpc corresponding to $2.22''$, which is small enough to cover a single pointing. To resolve molecular clumps on $Ysim1$ kpc scale, we choose $0.4"$ angular resolution.

We estimate the rms to detect $YSigma_{H2}=10$ $M_Yodot$ pc$^{-2}$ at the $5Ysigma$ level. The $1Ysigma$ rms is evaluated to be 2.83 mJy/beam using metallicity dependent conversion factor $Yalpha_{CO}$ of Genzel et al. (2012). We set the velocity resolution of $10$ km s$^{-1}$ assuming the molecular clump velocity width of $10$ km s$^{-1}$. The 468 MHz bandwidth is selected with referred to the CO line width obtained in previous study (Goncalves et al. 2014).

Goncalves et al. (2014) have found CO($J=1-0$) emission from this galaxy which shows double components peaked at $\sim-100$ and $\sim+130$ km s$^{-1}$ about systemic the velocity, respectively. In order to cover these two components and perform the profile fitting more accurately, we need the bandwidth more than $1200$ km s$^{-1} ($Ypm300$ km s$^{-1}$ about CO line). Thus we select 468 MHz bandwidth.

The galaxy has its diameter of $5.08$ kpc corresponding to $1.28''$, which is small enough to cover a single pointing. To resolve molecular clumps on $Ysim1$ kpc scale, we choose $0.2"$ angular resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose Band 3 observations for a CO($J=1-0$) line from $5$ local counterparts of high-$z$ galaxies. Our Band 3 observations will map out spatially-resolved molecular clumps traced by CO emission with a spatial resolution down to $Ysim1$ kpc. Combining HST images of our targets, we will investigate detailed spatial distributions of molecular clumps, star-forming regions, and stellar mass within the resemblances of high-$z$ galaxies. Our major goal is to derive a spatially-resolved Kennicutt-Schmidt (K-S) law, and to reveal physical mechanism of intense star-formation activity found in high-$z$ galaxies that is a long-standing question. Because recent studies report that high-$z$ galaxies have a high ionization parameter and gas fraction, we set secondary goals that are characterizing the state of inter-stellar medium from correlations between star-formation efficiency, gas fraction, UV-continuum/Ly$Yalpha$-line emission, and dust extinction of molecular clumps. Our correlation study will test the hypothesis whether neutral hydrogen density regulates Ly$Yalpha$ emissivity, which is actively discussed in high-$z$ galaxy studies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
